segments.title: From Hype to Public Policy
segments.subtitle: How to Govern AI in the Public Sector
segments.keyMessage: From technological hype to sustainable public policy

engagement.prompt: How is your organization currently approaching AI governance?

segments.notes: ABSTRACT: Artificial intelligence has moved from being a technological promise to becoming an everyday tool for governments and public administrations. However, the speed of its adoption exceeds institutional capacity to regulate, evaluate, and ensure alignment with the public interest. This conference proposes a critical journey from hype to public policy, exploring how States can govern AI from three dimensions: strategic (vision and planning), operational (capabilities and public procurement), and ethical (transparency, accountability, and equity). Drawing from international and Latin American experiences, guidelines for responsible and sustainable AI governance in the public sector will be presented.

segments.title: Why AI Governance Matters
segments.subtitle: The governance gap is now the biggest risk in AI adoption
bullets: Governments rushed to deploy AI ‚Äî but few built the institutions to govern it
The hype cycle of AI peaks faster than policy cycles
Public agencies often adopt AI tools before defining oversight
Result: uncertainty, risk, and lost trust

media.alt: AI Hype vs Policy Maturity Curve
media.caption: The gap between AI hype cycle and policy maturity

engagement.prompt: Has your organization experienced the gap between AI adoption and governance readiness?

segments.notes: The Gap: Governments around the world have rushed to adopt AI technologies, but governance frameworks lag behind. This creates risks: algorithmic bias goes unchecked, accountability is unclear, and public trust erodes. The challenge is not just technical‚Äîit's institutional.

segments.title: Strategic Layer: Vision & Planning
segments.subtitle: Without vision, AI becomes automation without direction
bullets: Vision & Coordination ‚Äî national AI strategies, cross-agency alignment
Capacity Building ‚Äî training digital public servants
Investment Alignment ‚Äî linking funding to measurable outcomes
segments.keyMessage: AI governance begins with a clear sense of purpose ‚Äî linking innovation to public value

media.caption: Three pillars of strategic AI governance

engagement.prompt: Does your country have a national AI strategy? How well is it coordinated across agencies?

segments.notes: Strategic governance is about setting direction. Countries like Finland and Estonia show that clear vision‚Äîcombined with institutional coordination‚Äîcreates the foundation for responsible AI adoption. Without strategy, AI deployment becomes reactive and fragmented.

segments.title: Operational Layer: Capabilities & Procurement
segments.subtitle: Procurement is where AI ethics meet bureaucracy
segments.keyMessage: Turning principles into practice requires operational muscle

engagement.prompt: How does your organization evaluate AI systems before procurement?

segments.notes: Operational governance translates strategy into action. Procurement is a critical lever: it determines which AI tools enter government, under what conditions, and with what accountability. Countries like Canada pioneered algorithmic impact assessments, but enforcement remains a challenge.

segments.title: Ethical Layer: Transparency & Accountability
segments.subtitle: Ethics are not a constraint ‚Äî they are the foundation of legitimacy
segments.keyMessage: Ethical AI in the public sector ensures legitimacy, trust, and fairness
implementationTools: Open audit logs and traceability dashboards

media.caption: The three pillars of ethical AI governance

engagement.prompt: What mechanisms does your organization use to ensure AI transparency and accountability?

segments.notes: Ethics in AI governance are not abstract principles‚Äîthey are operational requirements. Fairness, transparency, and accountability must be embedded in systems design, procurement, and oversight. Without them, AI erodes public trust rather than building it.

segments.title: Latin American Outlook
segments.subtitle: Latin America can leapfrog ‚Äî not by copying, but by co-creating
bullets: A region of contrasts: limited resources, high creativity
Brazil: National AI Strategy (EBIA) focused on public value
Colombia: GovDigital / ESAP innovation and institutional capacity building
Chile: Open data & civic innovation labs with early ethical frameworks
segments.keyMessage: Regional cooperation can turn challenges into opportunities

engagement.prompt: What unique opportunities does Latin America have to shape AI governance differently?

segments.notes: Latin America faces structural challenges‚Äîdigital divides, weak institutions, limited resources. But the region also has unique opportunities: strong civil society, innovative civic tech movements, and the potential for regional cooperation. By co-creating governance frameworks rather than importing them, Latin America can leapfrog.
